üåêüîã The landscape of nuclear energy is rapidly evolving, thanks in large part to the development of Small Modular Reactors (SMRs). As a passionate follower of this technology, I've been closely monitoring the progress of SMRs, which promise a safer, more efficient, and sustainable approach to nuclear power generation.

üá®üá≥üá∑üá∫ While China and Russia are at the forefront of this revolution, companies worldwide are racing to bring SMRs to the market. These compact reactors offer numerous advantages, such as exceptional passive safety features, reduced uranium enrichment requirements (some as low as 8.5%), and extended life cycles of up to 60 years.

üåéüå± SMRs have the potential to address many of the historical challenges associated with nuclear energy, including waste management. The latest report from the Nuclear Energy Agency (NEA) offers a comprehensive overview and dashboard of the current state of SMR technology.

A few years back, shady middlemen came to us with an "Energy Aggregation" ploy, where we were to buy "green energy" from a corrupt Ohio nuclear facility for 3X the cost that it was providing nuclear energy to Ohioans. 

#NJ27thLD raised the the issue through proper channels to @NJBPU and the @GovMurphy Administration.

Nothing.

Why were they selling us on our "Bulk Purchasing Power" when we should have already had an underlying systemic accountability to begin with?

If an Ohio nuclear facility can provide power at 4.8¬¢ per kWh, why can't our NJ nuclear facilities do the same? Which institutions hold the debt that artificially leverages "cost."

Good-intending citizens were being upsold on purchasing all their power as "green" with zero accountability for the commissions. We were being taken advantage of. Where was the NJBPU President to protect our interests?

To step forward into OSW now without ever having worked through the prior issues will leave us at the mercy of powerful players who apparently sit on both sides of traditional and renewable power, opening ourselves to decades of legal institutionalized racketeering on pricing. 

Rather than inching forward into the abyss, with stronger leadership we can take a big step back and impose a new underlying systemic accountability.   

And if OSW works, that's great, but show us the pro-formas. And somebody has got to honestly deal with the dead whale issue. Lastly, renewables only really make sense if the post-capitalization value accountably flows as savings to the ratepayer. 

It is time for a fresh approach to accounting for what it is that we actually value. We shouldn't need to wait for the next administration. The time to act is now.
